text: The typewriter separated composition from publication and turned the writer into his own typesetter.

You must type each key deliberately and firmly with the finger assigned to it in your typing manual - and don't lift your fingers too far away from the keyboard, since that only adds to the distance they must travel to hit the next key.
source: David McCullough, on his writing process

text: The first commercial typewriters were introduced in 1874, but did not become common in offices until the mid-1880s.
Christopher Latham Sholes, Carlos Glidden and Samuel W. Soule invented the first practical typewriter in Milwaukee, Wisconsin in 1868.
The QWERTY keyboard layout was designed to prevent jamming on mechanical typewriters by placing frequently used letter pairs far apart.
Mark Twain claimed to be the first author to submit a typewritten manuscript to a publisher with his work 'Life on the Mississippi' in 1883.
The shift key was introduced in the Remington No. 2 typewriter in 1878, allowing for both uppercase and lowercase letters on the same machine.
The electric typewriter was first patented in 1914, but did not become common until the 1950s.
The term 'typewriter' was first coined by its inventor, Christopher Latham Sholes, as both the name for the machine and its operator.
The average typing speed on a typewriter in the 1920s was about 30-40 words per minute for a professional typist.
The 'noiseless' typewriter was invented by Wellington Parker Kidder in 1909, using a different striking mechanism to reduce the characteristic clacking sound.
A typewriter is freedoms's window - it guarantees the right to a unique point of view.
The Dvorak keyboard layout, patented in 1936, was designed to be more efficient than QWERTY, but never achieved widespread adoption despite its proven advantages.
The IBM Selectric typewriter, introduced in 1961, replaced the traditional typebars with a spherical typing element called a 'golf ball', revolutionizing office typing.
By 1900, there were over 100 different manufacturers of typewriters in the United States alone.
source: Martin Howard Collection of Early Typewriters

text: The world's first typing contest was held in Cincinnati, Ohio in July 1888, where Louis Taub achieved a speed of 95 words per minute.
The typewriter helped open up secretarial positions to women; by 1890, nearly 64% of stenographers and typists in the United States were female.
source: U.S. Department of Labor, Historical Statistics

text: The last major manufacturer of typewriters, Godrej and Boyce in India, closed its production plant in 2011, marking the end of an era.
The practice of typing with all lowercase letters became common in the early days of telegraphy and typewriters, as it was faster not to use the shift key.
source: Bruce Bliven Jr., The Wonderful Writing Machine

text: Hemingway wrote standing up, facing his typewriter, which he placed on a bookshelf at chest height.
